children.string: Okay, I think I got this public thing to work, and was able to nab the `tuck` URL which is dope. I had to export then delete my private graph, export the old almost-public one, create this graph, and import the meant-to-be-public contents. Fresh.
BUT now for the downside - I can't import my private notes back into my old `ryantuck` graph because it says that duplicate blocks exist!
The [[Kurzgesagt]] video on [Climate Doom](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wbR-5mHI6bo) is really good.
This post looks like a cool summary of [[Roam]] automation: https://beepb00p.xyz/myinfra-roam.html

title: Repetition and wasted effort can kill motivation

children.string: Welcome. This is my public Roam graph. It's in-progress.
[[About]] [[Me]]
Indexed October 2020
[[Deep Work]]
[[How to Take Smart Notes]]
[[The Life Changing Magic of Tidying Up]]
[[Two Cheers for Anarchism]]
[[Stubborn Attachments]]
#WIP
[[Book Summaries]]
[[Becoming Ambidextrous]]
[[thoughtnugs]]
[[Ontology of Notes]]
#Radar
I'm Ryan Tuck, and this is my public Roam graph.
About, circa late 2020

I'm really intrigued by [[Roam]] having used it fairly extensively for the past few months. I had been building something myself that worked on local markdown files edited in `vim`, but have found it really nice to use a tool that is already feature-rich and really lovely to use.

I split my main graph a week ago into three separate graphs: work, private, and public. Putting hard barriers between information is really nice and removed the necessity to curate and parse my graph to figure out which part of it should be public, and hope that whatever python script I threw together to do so didn't have a bug that shipped my private stuff accidentally. Cost and friction associated with publishing are now zero.
My private graph is mostly just my implementation of [[GTD]]. Otherwise, the vast majority of my (backlinked, interconnected, futuristic) thinking is going to happen here.

My current "strategy" if one could call it that is to basically treat daily notes as a semi-stream-of-consciousness dumping ground, linking as I go or later on. I'll also make other random pages, like [[Me]], but I'll try to tie them back to the [[Index]] when I do, as it's the only guidepost as of [[October 27th, 2020]].
Removed from sidebar [[March 22nd, 2022]]
#log
Author:: Cal Newport
[[meta]]

**Deep work** is professional activity performed in a state of distraction-free concentration that pushes your cognitive capabilities to their limit. These efforts create new value, improve your skill, and are hard to replicate.
Contrast with shallow work: easy-to-replicate logistical tasks.
**The deep work hypothesis** states that deep work is becoming increasingly rare and valuable, so being able to do it is good.
"The satisfactions of manifesting oneself concretely in the world through manual competence have been known to make a man quiet and easy." - Matthew Crawford #quote
The hub-and-spoke model of work is ideal for deep work
The hub is a common place that allows for [[serendipity]], which is immensely valuable (as it was at [[Bell Labs]]).
The spoke is an isolated and distraction-free environment where deep work happens.
4DX: the four disciplines of execution
1. Focus on what's wildly important
2. Focus on lead measures
Opposite of lag measures
For deep work, the lead measure is hours spent in deep work!
3. Keep a scorecard
4. Set a cadence of accountability
A shutdown ritual helps to wrap up a day reliably around the same time
Offload what would be required to finish what I'm working on
Beware the "any-benefit" mindset
"Facebook provides a slight benefit in that I can get messaged there, so why not keep it?"
Productive meditation
Focused thinking about a specific problem while you're walking, jogging, etc.
Improves concentration and is effective (supposedly!)
Work depth heuristic
How long would it take a smart college grad to do this?
In other words, how long would it take to train someone to trust as myself at a meeting?
Things to try
Scheduling blocks through entire day (pp221)
Training concentration (pp159)
Author:: [[SÃ¶nke Ahrens]]

[[Niklas Luhmann]] invented the [[Zettelkasten]] note-taking method originally as slips of paper in a box. The main idea is that a graph of linked ideas is better suited to the process of thinking than a hierarchy of notes.
The core idea of linked notes is the important takeaway, even though [[Roam]] solves and changes a few of the core ideas from the physical implementation.
Act as though writing is the only thing that matters.
"No, no! They aren't a record of my thinking process. They are my thinking process. I actually did the work on the paper." - [[Richard Feynman]]
"One cannot think without writing." - [[Niklas Luhmann]]
The process of writing begins much, much earlier than the blank screen.
"Writing is not what follows research, learning or studying, it is the __medium__ of all this work." pp2
"Writing is, without dispute, the best facilitator for thinking, reading, learning, understanding, and generating ideas we have." pp22
[[Writing is thinking]]
"Do not brainstorm for a topic. Look into the slip-box instead to see where chains of notes have developed and ideas have been built up to clusters." pp25
Most notes will be found through other notes. The index can just serve as entrypoints.
Making links between notes isn't a chore. It's necessary maintenance.
"Liberating our brains from the task of organizing the notes is the main reason we use the slip-box in the first place." pp109
"... no underlined sentence will ever present itself when you need it in the development of an argument." pp44
A [[Zettelkasten]] is a tool for thought
A good note-taking system supports and encourages the wandering that is research
The goal is to have a note system as comprehensive as [[GTD]], but open-ended enough to support writing, learning, and thinking.
"those who take smart notes will never have the problem of the blank screen again." pp2
[[Environment]] matters more than inner strength when it comes to [[self-control]]. "Nobody needs willpower not to eat a chocolate bar when there isn't one around." pp3
"I never force myself to do anything I don't feel like. Whenever I am stuck, I do something else." - [[Niklas Luhmann]]
A good note-taking structure allows you to naturally wander from topic to topic without losing sight of the bigger picture.
"It is a huge misunderstanding that the only alternative to planning is aimless messing around."
Planning is often fundamentally at odds with research.
"It is certainly not the lack of interesting topics, but rather the employment of problematic work routines" that leads to a lack of control over the research process.
"We need a reliable and simple external structure to think in that compensates for the limitations of our brains." pp20
Optimize for retrieval, not storage
"In the old system, the question is: Under which topic do I store this note? In the new system, the question is: In which context will I want to stumble on this again?" pp40
All notes should ultimately be discoverable from the index.
Don't collect ideas. Develop them.
Types of notes
The **index** is the entrypoint into the [[Zettelkasten]]. Everything should be eventually discoverable from it.

**Fleeting notes** are the raw material of what will become permanent notes. Lower the barrier for entry, write down everything interesting, process them regularly by turning them into permanent notes, and delete by default.
Fleeting notes are akin to the inbox in [[GTD]]
Processing fleeting notes shortly after they're taken is easier because the importance and context are still relatively fresh.
**Literature notes** should be short, selective, and in my own words.
Use full sentences.
Link to sources and other ideas.
Be precise, clear, and brief.
Make one note for each idea.
"No thought is ever wasted on where to put or label [a note]." pp45
Some notes might be created and never found again, which is okay.
Relentlessly curate. Not every note is permanent! If everything is relevant, then nothing is relevant. Do not seek to re-create Wikipedia.
When you add a note, see about making connections to what already exists, as opposed to just linking to general categories and subjects.
**Permanent notes** are at the heart of the [[Zettelkasten]].
**Project notes** are utility notes to be archived once the project is complete.

title: The Life Changing Magic of Tidying Up

children.string: The Japanese art of decluttering and organizing

**Things play roles in our lives. Examining our relationships with the things we surround ourselves with through the process of discarding and tidying can be transformative. Determine what you want in your life before determining where to put it. Keep only what sparks joy. Fold your clothes; every piece of clothing has a way it wants to be folded. Every item needs a home. Optimize storage for writes, not reads. **
Chapters
1. Why can't I keep my house in order?
2. Finish discarding first
3. Tidying by category works like magic
4. Storing your things to make your life shine
5. The magic of tidying dramatically transforms your life
"The moment you first encounter a particular book is the right time to read it." pp95
Sometimes a thing's role is to show us what doesn't suit us, and we can thank the jacket or the mug for having played that role.
This is, of course, analogous to people.
"You'll be surprised at how many of the things you possess have already fulfilled their role." pp61
"To truly cherish the things that are important to you, you must first discard those that have outlived their purpose." pp61
Written information can have a big effect on the psyche. Be aware of how much you're exposed to that doesn't spark joy.
"At their core, the things we really like do not change over time. Putting your house in order is a great way to discover what they are." pp175
Tidying is a reflective experience.

"The things we own are real. They exist here and now as a result of choices made in the past by no one other than ourselves. It is dangerous to ignore them or to discard them indiscriminately as if denying the choices we made." pp183
"Human beings can only truly cherish a limited number of things at one time." pp203
[[Things play roles in our lives]]
__You should only tidy once, once and for all.__
**tl;dr: Start by discarding. Then organize your space, thoroughly, completely, in one go.**
Tidying should be a special event.
After the house is tidy and you put things back where they belong regularly, you no longer need to tidy.
One-shot cleaning is best because you'll only need to do it once.
"It's best to tackle one room at a time"
"It's better to do a little each day"
"Storage should follow the flow plan of the house"
Bad tidying advice, according to [[Marie Kondo]]
Visualizing what things will look like once you're tidy is helpful. [[Visualization]] at work.
Start with discarding
Tidying should be positive. "We should be choosing what we want to keep, not what we want to throw away." pp41
Determine what you want in your life before figuring out where it will go, as opposed to filling storage.
Don't put anything away until you're done discarding.
"Take the plunge" and discard your shit!
"Too many people live surrounded by things they don't need 'just because'." pp107
Reduce until you reach the point where something clicks.
Don't let your family see what you're getting rid of, because they might then keep it.
Papers
Throw all of your papers out unless they're:
Currently in use
Needed to keep for a limited time or indefinitely
Tidy in the right order: from easiest to most difficult
Sorting by category is necessary because ...
It provides a sense of volume to what we own that's easily missed when stuff is dispersed throughout the house.
[[Repetition and wasted effort can kill motivation]], so knock out everything in one shot to stay stoked.
Marie's recommended order:
Clothes
Books
Papers
__komono__ (random shit)
Break out into similar categories as needed
Sentimental things
"The moment you start focusing on __how__ to choose what to throw away, you have actually veered significantly off course." pp39
Be wary of the following when thinking of what to keep:
I can still use it
"Life becomes far easier once you know that things will still work out even if you are lacking something." pp187
It's got some helpful info
You can find this later
It's got sentimental value
I could never replace it
[[Does it spark joy?]]: the criteria for keeping things
Clothes
Get every article of clothing from everywhere, seriously.
Don't downgrade clothes you don't like to loungewear. Get rid of them.
Fold most of your clothes.
Bold claim: "you can fit from twenty to forty pieces of folded clothing in the same amount of space required to hang ten." pp72
Every piece of clothing has a sweet spot where it's been folded into a pretty perfect rectangle.
Folded clothes should be one layer deep in drawers so you can see everything at a glace.

Don't ball up your socks. This is not only so the elastic stays good if the socks are shit, but also just think about how much you can let them chill and breathe. This starts to border on [[woo]], but I think there's something to having this relationship with physical items.
Only hang things that look like they'd be happy hung up.
Arrange your clothes on hangers so they flow nicely.
Sentimental shit
Sentimental shit is gonna be way harder to tidy than clothes.
It's okay to get rid of gifts.
"Presents are not 'things' but a means for conveying someone's feelings." pp108
Handling sentimental things and deciding what to discard is a form of processing the past.
Your house will tell you where things go
[[Everyone needs a sanctuary]] pp 140
"Storage experts are hoarders"
Storage solutions are generally a bandage to the real problem of you just absolutely having too much shit.
Drawers are better than tubs because they lower the barrier to entry for looking inside.
Every item needs a home.
Anything without one increases the odds clutter will return.
Two rules for storage
Store all similar items in the same place
Don't scatter storage space
Storage should optimize for writes, not reads.
The faster we can write clutter to storage, the easier tidying is.
Clutter is a big mix of crap we want to process as fast as possible, whereas we often query storage with greater intention, knowing what it is we want to retrieve.
Where things are stored changes our behavior just as much as we change where things are stored to suit ours in the first place.
This is a more specific instance of [[Nature versus Nurture]], or bi-directional causal arrows between me and the environment.
"When you are choosing what to keep, ask your heart; when you are choosing where to store something, ask your house." pp144
"Never pile things" pp144
Kitchen
Counters shouldn't be used for storage.
Bottles etc make it way harder to clean kitchen surfaces than it should be.
#WIP - notes for intro
Author:: [[Tyler Cowen]]
[[meta]]
Economic growth correlates with better and happier lives.
Stubborn Attachments makes the moral case for economic growth.
[[Growth is good]].
"We need to develop a tougher, more dedicated, and indeed a more stubborn attachment to prosperity and freedom." pp15
Premises of argument
Questions of right and wrong have correct answers, even if they're tough to pin down and even though there's moral gray areas.
"Relativism is a non-starter, and most people are not sincere in their relativist pronouncements anyway." pp16
"We need to be more modest when it comes to what we can possibly know"
"I hold pluralism as a core moral intuition." pp17
"and thus, there is a fundamental messiness to the nature of the good."
Economists often argue that satisfying people's preferences encapsulates all other relevant values, so using it as a proxy value is justified.
Cowen thinks this is wrong.
"when we condemn a man who beats his wife, must we really calculate whether the suffering exceeds the pleasure of the hitter? I think not." pp18
Cowen calls himself a "two-thirds utliitarian"
"We should not end civilization to do what is just, but justice does sometimes trump utility." pp18
Six critical issues to investigate
"How should we weight the interests of the present against the more distant future?" pp19
How should we aggregate preferences among individuals?
The Arrow and Sen impossibility theorems suggest this problem is difficult and might be intractible.
How should we use rules in our lives?
"Can we generate a coherent morality in which we respect rules and principles for their own sake?"

"Given such long-run uncertainty, how can we possibly pretend to assess the good and bad consequences of our actions? How can we make any decision at all without succumbing to moral paralysis and total uncertainty?" pp22
"How can we use our epistemic modesty to make better choices?" pp22
How do rights fit in?

"Common sense morality holds that we should work hard, take care of our families, and live virtuous but self-centered lives, while giving to charity as we are able and helping out others on a periodic basis." pp23
Common sense morality stands in contrast to utilitarianism.
The productive power of economies should not be taken for granted.
"For all her failings, Ayn Rand is the one writer who has best understood the importance of production to moral theory." pp24
"It is the work of capital, labor, and natural resources, driven by the creative individual mind, which undergird the achievements of our civilization." pp24
"I will seek to revise some of our intuitive assumptions about moral distance." pp24
The Octopus - [[Frank Norris]]
**Hello, World. **Just burned the existing Roam graph to the ground and starting this one over in public.
Yes, I exported everything first and saved it in a separate private graph. I'm not a lunatic.

Looking forward to partaking in this grand experiment of thinking in public. My main goal here was to limit the friction involved with publishing. I've found [twitter](https://twitter.com/ryntck) to be a useful avenue for thinking and engaging in the public square, but having a more established and persistent presence with more control over the structure seems attractive.

Initially, the goal was going to be to parse my single Roam graph using [pyroam](https://github.com/ryantuck/pyroam) and then ship a subset of the graph up to my site at [ryantuck.io](http://ryantuck.io), but in order to avoid figuring out exactly which nodes to include, hooking up CI, figuring out deployment, yatta yatta yatta, three months go by and I never prioritize getting it out the door -- I decided to go this route first.
I suppose an [[Index]] of sorts would be in order, first and foremost.
Alright, first page done. Now for copying over two book summaries that are ready to go and hilariously on-the-nose for being the first notes in a public Roam graph.
[[How to Take Smart Notes]]
[[Deep Work]]
And while we're at it, some work-in-progress on [[Stubborn Attachments]] by [[Tyler Cowen]].
A list of a few more things I'd like to bring over:
My current [[GTD]] setup in [[Roam]] that's been working pretty well over the past few months
And a smattering of some other random thoughts that seem appropriate to help start a graph of understanding:
[[Hanlon's Razor]] states: "Do not ascribe to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity."
The [[Overton Window]] is the range of acceptable discourse within a group
[[Motte and Bailey]] is a rhetorical device where you make a strong argument in the bailey and then retreat to the motte with a more palatable argument when challenged.
Any one-hump equation will give rise to a very similar graph as $$r$$ is increased.
The [[Mandelbrot Set]] lies in the complex plane and lines up with the logistic map. 3D diagram of this is sweet.
The interesting thing is that there are periods of stability followed by chaos followed by stability. It's fractal, it's fucking nuts.

[This youtube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ovJcsL7vyrk) covers [[the logistic map]], which is the equation $$x_{n+1} = rx_n(1 - x_n)$$. It's remarkable. It covers the [[Feigenbaum Constant]] and [[Chaos]].
An app to play your Spotify songs but add CD skip effects or the need to switch a tape over if you're feeling nostalgic.
Organization condenses information in space.
A hammock office chair made entirely of rope, infinitely adjustable.
Grandma as a service.
Birchbox for tools.
Solving the rent-a-drill problem could be a billion dollar business.
A lockbox in front of your house and an app hookup.
Surge pricing
Enable drivers to pick stuff up and deliver it.

With sufficiently-advanced technology, could we make up for the obscene suffering of billions of sentient creatures through factory farming by creating glorious virtual worlds for billions of cows, pigs, chickens, and fish to inhabit to happily flourish? To what extent will there still be a debt owed once the last factory farm is banned? To whom do we pay that debt?

So anyway, idea seeds, with little-to-no polish, are instead [[thoughtnugs]], and here are some examples. I wouldn't bet on these, don't feel beholden to defending them, and also don't mind if they sound overly confident and vague like some bullshit you might find on fortune cookie twitter. Broadly speaking, they're fodder for thought.

I've been seeking metaphors to use for defining the [[Ontology of Notes]]. The primary metaphor out there is of a garden, with ideas being seeds at first, and growing eventually into evergreen notes. I fully buy into that spirit, but want to create my own ontology to best suit my needs and force me to think through what it should look like.
Ooh, try something like accent colors https://github.com/linuz90/better-roam-research#change-accent-color
[[rtcss]]
It will never not amaze me how every outdoor table at a cafe or restaurant inevitably wobbles, and that everyone in the world seems to think this is a fine state of affairs.

I feel I likely have a religious attitude towards freedom of speech and liberalism generally. They still rationally sing to me, but in the spirit of recognizing my own biases, it's worth keeping an eye out for.
Install `z`.
Oh, this is lovely: modern digital public correspondences at [Letter](https://letter.wiki/conversation/930#letter_3081). Might be the sweet spot between twitter and substack.

Yesterday I [posted](https://twitter.com/ryntck/status/1319377263020986370) about [[Becoming Ambidextrous]]. It would be really interesting to track progress. The right side of my body feels comically awkward compared to my left side, and I'd love to balance that out.
#books Man's Search for Meaning by Victor Frankl.

title: Things play roles in our lives

children.string: Last night I plowed through [[Marie Kondo]]'s [[The Life Changing Magic of Tidying Up]] and it was wonderful. Highlight to page count really high!

Also just started using a [Swiffer duster](https://www.amazon.com/Swiffer-Dusters-Extendable-Handle-Starter/dp/B001TQ6IHS) and it's so great. [[Disposability]] obviously has its drawbacks, but the upside of impermanent shit like plastic bags (arguably one of the greatest inventions of the twentieth century) is almost never appreciated. The background noise of our lives.
âIf you want a picture of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human faceâfor ever.â - [[George Orwell]], [[1984]]

What does extreme knowledge work look like? Is there a limit to the scalability of GTD or, assuming maximum efficiency in going from inbox to knowledge graph, does the utility start to plateau or even decrease as the size of data comes in? This is somewhat [[half-baked]].

Attempting to use the sort-references [Roam JS script](https://roam.davidvargas.me/extensions/sort-references/). It works as advertised. Super handy. I'd like to explore fairly extensive Roam hacking.
{{[[roam/js]]}}
And we're public. Hello again, world. See [[October 18th, 2020]] for more about this graph.
Very cool, I just stumbled on my good friend [Chris Becker](http://www.becker.am) on [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/@chrisbecker). What are the odds of that??

Maybe about ten people I know who take photography sufficiently seriously. Lots more than that on Unsplash. Even accounting for all the people I know being obviously above-average photographers, it still seems unlikely. On top of that, I only waded through like 20 photos.
N photos = 20
N people = 10
N unsplash photographers = 200k
Naive assumptions
All ten people I know are on Unsplash
The 20 pics I saw were a random sample of one photo each of 20 randomly chosen photographers
P(20 photos without finding a friend) = (1 - P(find friend))^20
P(20 photos without finding a friend) = (99.995%)^20 = **99.90%**
Yeah, pretty unlikely!

Installing an "extension" by clicking a link to add a snippet of javascript to a bookmarks bar link is an interesting install method for software. It's really nice and lightweight. What are its benefits compared to an extension?
It's genuinely remarkable how trivially simple [[Roam]]'s data model is. As a result, creating a different view layer on top of your exported graph does seem super doable.
[Dendron](https://www.dendron.so/notes/7fcebd7d-6411-4c9d-8baf-65629dc018a1.html) is another note-taking tool that's very close to [[Roam]].

I have experience with databases and applications and sufficient technical chops to have to figure this out myself after a week of radio silence from support and no response via the official @RoamResearch twitter account. I'd hate to be a non-technical user of Roam after this and still be paying $15 a month for that kind of pure apathy.

First every shitty experience with [[Roam]] has been re-importing exported notes into an existing private graph. Wrote a bit about it here, and how I ended up debugging and ultimately fixing it: https://twitter.com/ryntck/status/1320825090309787649
What is the right tax system?
Is liberalism the best equilibrium state for global civilization? Is it even a meaningful equilibrium state?
A good way to bootstrap a knowledge graph is to create at least one sentence or one paragraph summaries of books I know something about and have read.
[[Candide]] by [[Voltaire]] is one of the best books I've ever read.

My latest bullshit system seems kind of good. The fact that there's no Roam app means I can only access my todos on my laptop, so I'm trying out the basic Mac Reminders app. It has the usual Apple software quirks of not being friendly to power users and being generally kind of barebones and shitty, but I can at least share a todo list with my wife, who's not a Roam user. For my work graph, I can still kick it with Roam TODOs.

"Bullshit system" might be the right name for a productivity system. Some rote processing void where you can throw the neverending little bullshit of life to get taken care of - errands, chores, reminders. GTD helps to process bullshit.

One thing I've been doing recently is writing down memories as they randomly arise, to try to slowly compile an autobiography. Will likely move this over into this public graph soon, as I plan to do with most things.
Another thing to slowly generate is a [[Groceries]] list, which would likely expand to a general inventory list.
I should update the CSS for this graph to make it cool, like a myspace page.
"[[Scientism]] is the promotion of science as the best or only objective means by which society should determine normative and epistemological values."
Seemingly related to [[Scientism]], though from Wikipedia's definition, they seem sufficiently different.

I recently thought of [[Richard Feynman]]'s [[Cargo Cult Science]] speech and how it relates to the "I believe in Science" claim in pop culture. Reciting a statistic or claim as solid fact as opposed to a highly context-dependent result without having confirmed it yourself strikes me as unethical. Physics truths are terse; little else is.
Notes as a city
Neighborhoods, development, actors, trade-offs, explorable
Ideas can be shops, restaurants, the subway, the sewage, anything, really
There are echoes of [[Plato]]'s [[Republic]] here that would, I'm sure, be quite on-the-nose.
More thinking on the [[Ontology of Notes]]
My grandfather just recommended Queen's Gambit on Netflix about [[Chess]].

There's something to be said for changing defaults. This morning I didn't check instagram and twitter before getting out of bed, and recognized the times when I would find myself mindlessly creating a new tab or picking up my phone. Being in the driver's seat feels alright sometimes!
It is remarkable how helpful `Makefile`s are within a repo. Ideally, they should serve as the tl;dr, the table of contents, and the cockpit all at once.
What is the Makefile of a physics education?
Something else to write about to keep me intellectually honest would be my equation tattoos and their proofs and explanations.

By [[Richard Feynman]]
**Some remarks on science, pseudoscience, and learning how to not fool yourself. Caltechâs 1974 commencement address.**

During the Middle Ages there were all kinds of crazy ideas, such as that a piece of rhinoceros horn would increase potency.Â Â (Another crazy idea of the Middle Ages is these hats we have on todayâwhich is too loose in my case.)Â Â Then a method was discovered for separating the ideasâwhich was to try one to see if it worked, and if it didnât work, to eliminate it.Â Â This method became organized, of course, into science.Â Â And it developed very well, so that we are now in the scientific age.Â Â It is such a scientific age, in fact, that we have difficulty in understanding howÂ­ witch doctors couldÂ __ever__Â have existed, when nothing that they proposed ever really workedâor very little of it did.

But even today I meet lots of people who sooner or later get me into a conversation about UFOâs, or astrology, or some form of mysticism, expanded consciousness, new types of awareness, ESP, and so forth.Â Â And Iâve concluded that itâsÂ __notÂ __a scientific world.

Most people believe so many wonderful things that I decided to investigate why they did.Â Â And what has been referred to as my curiosity for investigation has landed me in a difficulty where I found so much junk to talk about that I canât do it in this talk.Â Â Iâm overwhelmed.Â Â First I started out by investigating various ideas of mysticism, and mystic experiences.Â Â I went into isolation tanks (theyâre dark and quiet and you float in Epsom salts) and got many hours of hallucinations, so I know something about that.Â Â Then I went to Esalen, which is a hotbed of this kind of thought (itâs a wonderful place; you should go visit there). Then I became overwhelmed. I didnât realize howÂ __muchÂ __there was.

I was sitting, for example, in a hot bath and thereâs another guy and a girl in the bath.Â Â He says to the girl, âIâm learning massage and I wonder if I could practice on you?âÂ Â She says OK, so she gets up on a table and he starts off on her footâworking on her big toe and pushing it around.Â Â Then he turns to what is apparently his instructor, and says, âI feel a kind of dent.Â Â Is that the pituitary?âÂ Â And she says, âNo, thatâs not the way it feels.â I say, âYouâre a hell of a long way from the pituitary, man.âÂ Â And they both looked at meâI had blown my cover, you seeâand she said, âItâs reflexology.âÂ Â So I closed my eyes and appeared to be meditating.

Thatâs just an example of the kind of things that overwhelm me.Â Â I also looked into extrasensory perception and PSI phenomena, and the latest craze there was Uri Geller, a man who is supposed to be able to bend keys by rubbing them with his finger.Â Â So I went to his hotel room, on his invitation, to see a demonstration of both mind reading and bending keys.Â Â He didnât do any mind reading that succeeded; nobody can read my mind, I guess.Â Â And my boy held a key and Geller rubbed it, and nothing happened.Â Â Then he told us it works better under water, and so you can picture all of us standing in the bathroom with the water turned on and the key under it, and him rubbing the key with his finger.Â Â Nothing happened.Â Â So I was unable to investigate that phenomenon.

But then I began to think, what else is there that we believe?Â Â (And I thought then about the witch doctors, and how easy it would have been to check on them by noticing that nothing really worked.)Â Â So I found things that even more people believe, such as that we have some knowledge of how to educate.Â Â There are big schools of reading methods and mathematics methods, and so forth, but if you notice, youâll see the reading scores keep going downâor hardly going upâin spite of the fact that we continually use these same people to improve the methods.Â Â __Thereâs__Â a witch doctor remedy that doesnât work.Â Â It ought to be looked into: how do they know that their method should work?Â Â Another example is how to treat criminals.Â Â We obviously have made no progressâlots of theory, but no progressâin decreasing the amount of crime by the method that we use to handle criminals.

Yet these things are said to be scientific.Â Â We study them.Â Â And I think ordinary people with commonsense ideas are intimidated by this pseudoscience.Â Â A teacher who has some good idea of how to teach her children to read is forced by the school system to do it some other wayâor is even fooled by the school system into thinking that her method is not necessarily a good one.Â Â Or a parent of bad boys, after disciplining them in one way or another, feels guilty for the rest of her life because she didnât do âthe right thing,â according to the experts.
So we really ought to look into theories that donât work, and science that isnât science.

I tried to find a principle for discovering more of these kinds of things, and came up with the following system.Â Â Any time you find yourself in a conversation at a cocktail partyâin which you do not feel uncomfortable that the hostess might come around and say, âWhy are you fellows talking shop?ââ or that your wife will come around and say, âWhy are you flirting again?ââthen you can be sure you are talking about something about which nobody knows anything.

Using this method, I discovered a few more topics that I had forgottenâamong them the efficacy of various forms of psychotherapy.Â Â So I began to investigate through the library, and so on, and I have so much to tell you that I canât do it at all.Â Â I will have to limit myself to just a few little things.Â Â Iâll concentrate on the things more people believe in.Â Â Maybe I will give a series of speeches next year on all these subjects.Â Â It will take a long time.

> I think the educational and psychological studies I mentioned are examples of what I would like to call Cargo Cult Science.Â Â In the South Seas there is a Cargo Cult of people.Â Â During the war they saw airplanes land with lots of good materials, and they want the same thing to happen now.Â Â So theyâve arranged to make things like runways, to put fires along the sides of the runways, to make a wooden hut for a man to sit in, with two wooden pieces on his head like headphones and bars of bamboo sticking out like antennasâheâs the controllerâand they wait for the airplanes to land.Â Â Theyâre doing everything right.Â Â The form is perfect.Â Â It looks exactly the way it looked before.Â Â But it doesnât work.Â Â No airplanes land.Â Â So I call these things Cargo Cult Science, because they follow all the apparent precepts and forms of scientific investigation, but theyâre missing something essential, because the planes donât land.

Now it behooves me, of course, to tell you what theyâre missing.Â Â But it would he just about as difficult to explain to the South Sea Islanders how they have to arrange things so that they get some wealth in their system.Â Â It is not something simple like telling them how to improve the shapes of the earphones.Â Â But there isÂ __one__Â feature I notice that is generally missing in Cargo Cult Science.Â Â That is the idea that we all hope you have learned in studying science in schoolâwe never explicitly say what thisÂ __is__, but just hope that you catch on by all the examples of scientific investigation.Â Â It is interesting, therefore, to bring it out now and speak of it explicitly.Â Â Itâs a kind of scientific integrity, a principle of scientific thought that corresponds to a kind of utter honestyâa kind of leaning over backwards.Â Â For example, if youâre doing an experiment, you should report everything that you think might make it invalidânot only what you think is right about it: other causes that could possibly explain your results; and things you thought of that youâve eliminated by some other experiment, and how they workedâto make sure the other fellow can tell they have been eliminated.

Details that could throw doubt on your interpretation must be given, if you know them.Â Â You must do the best you canâif you know anything at all wrong, or possibly wrongâto explain it.Â Â If you make a theory, for example, and advertise it, or put it out, then you must also put down all the facts that disagree with it, as well as those that agree with it.Â Â There is also a more subtle problem.Â Â When you have put a lot of ideas together to make an elaborate theory, you want to make sure, when explaining what it fits, that those things it fits are not just the things that gave you the idea for the theory; but that the finished theory makes something else come out right, in addition.

In summary, the idea is to try to giveÂ __all__Â of the information to help others to judge the value of your contribution; not just the information that leads to judgment in one particular direction or another.

The easiest way to explain this idea is to contrast it, for example, with advertising.Â Â Last night I heard that Wesson Oil doesnât soak through food.Â Â Well, thatâs true.Â Â Itâs not dishonest; but the thing Iâm talking about is not just a matter of not being dishonest, itâs a matter of scientific integrity, which is another level.Â Â The fact that should be added to that advertising statement is thatÂ __no__Â oils soak through food, if operated at a certain temperature.Â Â If operated at another temperature, theyÂ __allÂ __willâincluding Wesson Oil.Â Â So itâs the implication which has been conveyed, not the fact, which is true, and the difference is what we have to deal with.

Weâve learned from experience that the truth will out.Â Â Other experimenters will repeat your experiment and find out whether you were wrong or right.Â Â Natureâs phenomena will agree or theyâll disagree with your theory.Â Â And, although you may gain some temporary fame and excitement, you will not gain a good reputation as a scientist if you havenât tried to be very careful in this kind of work.Â Â And itâs this type of integrity, this kind of care not to fool yourself, that is missing to a large extent in much of the research in Cargo Cult Science.

A great deal of their difficulty is, of course, the difficulty of the subject and the inapplicability of the scientific method to the subject.Â Â Nevertheless, it should be remarked that this is not the only difficulty.Â Â ThatâsÂ __why__Â the planes donât landâbut they donât land.

We have learned a lot from experience about how to handle some of the ways we fool ourselves.Â Â One example: Millikan measured the charge on an electron by an experiment with falling oil drops and got an answer which we now know not to be quite right.Â Â Itâs a little bit off, because he had the incorrect value for the viscosity of air.Â Â Itâs interesting to look at the history of measurements of the charge of the electron, after Millikan.Â Â If you plot them as a function of time, you find that one is a little bigger than Millikanâs, and the next oneâs a little bit bigger than that, and the next oneâs a little bit bigger than that, until finally they settle down to a number which is higher.

Why didnât they discover that the new number was higher right away?Â Â Itâs a thing that scientists are ashamed ofâthis historyâbecause itâs apparent that people did things like this: When they got a number that was too high above Millikanâs, they thought something must be wrongâand they would look for and find a reason why something might be wrong.Â Â When they got a number closer to Millikanâs value they didnât look so hard.Â Â And so they eliminated the numbers that were too far off, and did other things like that.Â Â Weâve learned those tricks nowadays, and now we donât have that kind of a disease.

But this long history of learning how to not fool ourselvesâof having utter scientific integrityâis, Iâm sorry to say, something that we havenât specifically included in any particular course that I know of.Â Â We just hope youâve caught on by osmosis.

The first principle is that you must not fool yourselfâand you are the easiest person to fool.Â Â So you have to be very careful about that.Â Â After youâve not fooled yourself, itâs easy not to fool other scientists.Â Â You just have to be honest in a conventional way after that.

> I would like to add something thatâs not essential to the science, but something I kind of believe, which is that you should not fool the layman when youâre talking as a scientist. Iâm not trying to tell you what to do about cheating on your wife, or fooling your girlfriend, or something like that, when youâre not trying to be a scientist, but just trying to be an ordinary human being.Â Â Weâll leave those problems up to you and your rabbi.Â Â Iâm talking about a specific, extra type of integrity that is not lying, but bending over backwards to show how youâre maybe wrong, that you ought to do when acting as a scientist.Â Â And this is our responsibility as scientists, certainly to other scientists, and I think to laymen.

For example, I was a little surprised when I was talking to a friend who was going to go on the radio.Â Â He does work on cosmology and astronomy, and he wondered how he would explain what the applications of this work were.Â Â âWell,â I said, âthere arenât any.âÂ Â He said, âYes, but then we wonât get support for more research of this kind.âÂ Â I think thatâs kind of dishonest.Â Â If youâre representing yourself as a scientist, then you should explain to the layman what youâre doingâand if they donât want to support you under those circumstances, then thatâs their decision.

One example of the principle is this: If youâve made up your mind to test a theory, or you want to explain some idea, you should always decide to publish it whichever way it comes out.Â Â If we only publish results of a certain kind, we can make the argument look good.Â Â We must publishÂ __bothÂ __kinds of result.Â Â For exampleâletâs take advertising againâsuppose some particular cigarette has some particular property, like low nicotine.Â Â Itâs published widely by the company that this means it is good for youâthey donât say, for instance, that the tars are a different proportion, or that something else is the matter with the cigarette.Â Â In other words, publication probability depends upon the answer.Â Â That should not be done.

I say thatâs also important in giving certain types of government advice. Supposing a senator asked you for advice about whether drilling a hole should be done in his state; and you decide it would he better in some other state.Â Â If you donât publish such a result, it seems to me youâre not giving scientific advice.Â Â Youâre being used.Â Â If your answer happens to come out in the direction the government or the politicians like, they can use it as an argument in their favor; if it comes out the other way, they donât publish it at all.Â Â Thatâs not giving scientific advice.

Other kinds of errors are more characteristic of poor science.Â Â When I was at Cornell.Â Â I often talked to the people in the psychology department.Â Â One of the students told me she wanted to do an experiment that went something like thisâI donât remember it in detail, but it had been found by others that under certain circumstances, X, rats did something, A.Â Â She was curious as to whether, if she changed the circumstances to Y, they would still do, A.Â Â So her proposal was to do the experiment under circumstances Y and see if they still did A.

I explained to her that it was necessary first to repeat in her laboratory the experiment of the other personâto do it under condition X to see if she could also get result Aâand then change to Y and see if A changed.Â Â Then she would know that the real difference was the thing she thought she had under control.

She was very delighted with this new idea, and went to her professor.Â Â And his reply was, no, you cannot do that, because the experiment has already been done and you would be wasting time.Â Â This was in about 1935 or so, and it seems to have been the general policy then to not try to repeat psychological experiments, but only to change the conditions and see what happens.

Nowadays thereâs a certain danger of the same thing happening, even in the famous field of physics.Â Â I was shocked to hear of an experiment done at the big accelerator at the National Accelerator Laboratory, where a person used deuterium.Â Â In order to compare his heavy hydrogen results to what might happen to light hydrogen he had to use data from someone elseâs experiment on light hydrogen, which was done on different apparatus.Â Â When asked he said it was because he couldnât get time on the program (because thereâs so little time and itâs such expensive apparatus) to do the experiment with light hydrogen on this apparatus because there wouldnât be any new result.Â Â And so the men in charge of programs at NAL are so anxious for new results, in order to get more money to keep the thing going for public relations purposes, they are destroyingâpossiblyâthe value of the experiments themselves, which is the whole purpose of the thing.Â Â It is often hard for the experimenters there to complete their work as their scientific integrity demands.

All experiments in psychology are not of this type, however.Â Â For example, there have been many experiments running rats through all kinds of mazes, and so onâwith little clear result.Â Â But in 1937 a man named Young did a very interesting one.Â Â He had a long corridor with doors all along one side where the rats came in, and doors along the other side where the food was.Â Â He wanted to see if he could train the rats to go in at the third door down from wherever he started them off.Â Â No.Â Â The rats went immediately to the door where the food had been the time before.

The question was, how did the rats know, because the corridor was so beautifully built and so uniform, that this was the same door as before?Â Â Obviously there was something about the door that was different from the other doors.Â Â So he painted the doors very carefully, arranging the textures on the faces of the doors exactly the same.Â Â Still the rats could tell.Â Â Then he thought maybe the rats were smelling the food, so he used chemicals to change the smell after each run.Â Â Still the rats could tell.Â Â Then he realized the rats might be able to tell by seeing the lights and the arrangement in the laboratory like any commonsense person.Â Â So he covered the corridor, and, still the rats could tell.

He finally found that they could tell by the way the floor sounded when they ran over it.Â Â And he could only fix that by putting his corridor in sand.Â Â So he covered one after another of all possible clues and finally was able to fool the rats so that they had to learn to go in the third door.Â Â If he relaxed any of his conditions, the rats could tell.

Now, from a scientific standpoint, that is an AâNumberâl experiment. That is the experiment that makes ratârunning experiments sensible, because it uncovers the clues that the rat is really usingânot what you think itâs using.Â Â And that is the experiment that tells exactly what conditions you have to use in order to be careful and control everything in an experiment with ratârunning.

I looked into the subsequent history of this research.Â Â The subsequent experiment, and the one after that, never referred to Mr. Young.Â Â They never used any of his criteria of putting the corridor on sand, or being very careful.Â Â They just went right on running rats in the same old way, and paid no attention to the great discoveries of Mr. Young, and his papers are not referred to, because he didnât discover anything about the rats.Â Â In fact, he discoveredÂ __all__Â the things you have to do to discover something about rats.Â Â But not paying attention to experiments like that is a characteristic of Cargo Cult Science.

Another example is the ESP experiments of Mr. Rhine, and other people.Â Â As various people have made criticismsâand they themselves have made criticisms of their own experimentsâthey improve the techniques so that the effects are smaller, and smaller, and smaller until they gradually disappear.Â Â All the parapsychologists are looking for some experiment that can be repeatedâthat you can do again and get the same effectâstatistically, even.Â Â They run a million ratsâno, itâs people this timeâthey do a lot of things and get a certain statistical effect.Â Â Next time they try it they donât get it any more.Â Â And now you find a man saying that it is an irrelevant demand to expect a repeatable experiment.Â Â This isÂ __science__?

This man also speaks about a new institution, in a talk in which he was resigning as Director of the Institute of Parapsychology.Â Â And, in telling people what to do next, he says that one of the things they have to do is be sure they only train students who have shown their ability to get PSI results to an acceptable extentânot to waste their time on those ambitious and interested students who get only chance results.Â Â It is very dangerous to have such a policy in teachingâto teach students only how to get certain results, rather than how to do an experiment with scientific integrity.

> So I wish to youâI have no more time, so I have just one wish for youâthe good luck to be somewhere where you are free to maintain the kind of integrity I have described, and where you do not feel forced by a need to maintain your position in the organization, or financial support, or so on, to lose your integrity.Â Â May you have that freedom.Â Â May I also give you one last bit of advice: Never say that youâll give a talk unless you know clearly what youâre going to talk about and more or less what youâre going to say.

Adding a 5-minute cycling background image to my machine and not using full-screen apps on my big external monitor is a kind of neat computing experience. Feels very vintage.

This year is the first where I've found the transition to Fall to be welcome. Or, if not welcome, at least not resisted. The leaves are beautiful. The onset of Halloween feels somewhat normal. These three months of ritual towards the Winter Solstice are really necessary while we brace for the cold. Why isn't there something else in January and February outside of Valentine's Day?

Phone calls for catching up are odd. Scheduling them feels too forced, but assuming someone's got a random half hour to bullshit and isn't already doing something else isn't a great assumption either.

I don't think I've ever read a piece on [[How to Look Shit Up Online]]. It might be worth writing. It's so fundamental and we all do it, but I imagine the process isn't really explicitly thought out. Honestly not sure if I've ever really reflected on my own, for that matter.
I wonder whether a more structured version of Slack could be interesting.
Here's another way to run data modeling stacks using python instead of SQL.
The premise is that python might be more readable than SQL.

I would want something as close to BigQuery performance as I could get, and I'd honestly prefer to define things __declaratively__ as opposed to imperatively. In other words, just say what I want done to given objects at various stages of transformation, and trust the tool to make it happen, scaling horizontally as needed.
Being able to opt for an imperative approach would be good functionality to support.
As an aside, I fully realize I might be re-describing Luigi or Spark or something that someone has already built. I'm coming at this asking "what would dbt in python look like?"
Meh, this is kinda half-baked. Worth thinking more about, but I do think I'm roughly describing [Spark](https://spark.apache.org/) which I haven't used.

All databases are required to be auditable by law due to some catastrophic cyberattack scenario that humanity survived. [[Blockchain]] is chosen as the underlying technology for it. We recognized the need for [[Turnkey Totalitarianism]], or a master switch to automatically override all digital operations (or some critical subset of them ) on the planet.

The framers of the new digital constitution try to constrain the exercise of power by requiring any access to a user's past data also be publicly auditable, and the request must be approved by a sufficiently objective third party.

People generally end up accepting this state of affairs. It seems pretty similar to minority report, but without the need for oracles. Since most people are law-abiding anyway, and crime went down, nobody is exactly opposing it.
Sci-Fi novel idea, somewhat related to [[Sam Harris]]'s idea of [[Turnkey Totalitarianism]]
It's odd to think that some information lives in physical form only for many of us, on health insurance cards, voter registration paperwork.

From [[Hacker News]]: [Managing my personal server in 2020](https://github.com/erebe/personal-server/blob/master/README.md)
Been working on a big project at work to replace a legacy service via a rewrite, and wanna get a few thoughts down about it.
The existing service is a bit of a black box. Therefore, my goal is to write code that, for a given input, produces an identical output as the old system.
There's a decent amount of input data hanging out in S3, and the outputs from the old system. Downloading all of S3 locally isn't an option, so network latency is necessarily a concern.

In my case, what this meant was to read in a single, minimal object with maybe one field, produce the corresponding minimal output, reduce the expected output, and then compare those two output objects.

This was still a substantial amount of work, but I think the main takeaway is that the skeleton was all I needed to focus on at that point, without getting bogged down in attribute-level specifics or scaling.

Once this was set up, I simply had a list of a couple dozen attributes of the various objects I needed to compare, and was able to whittle through them one at a time. Since I had wrote the code anticipating scaling, switching from two to one hundred input test cases was fairly trivial as well.
Basically, deep critical thinking is hard to bootstrap on-demand, so try to set your future self up for success by minimizing the amount required to accomplish a task at hand.
This certainly isn't novel, I'm sure.

This was also probably my first meaningful experience with [[Test-Driven Development]], and the primary thing I found so helpful is that, after a point, __all programming is debugging__, which turns it into grunt work to bang through, decoupled from the architecture thinking work that was needed beforehand.
I could then leverage [[nodemon]] to just constantly rerun my tests as I worked: `nodemon --exec pytest tests`

I tried to implement a [[Tracer Bullet]] setup as described in [[The Pragmatic Programmer]] for this project and found it to be extremely useful! Namely, MVP each layer of the full stack, and then expand on those layers.

Another thing I found really handy was to regularly add `# TODO` and `# NOTE` comments in appropriate places in code when I thought of them, so I could always just bang through that as a todo list if I was stuck.
Having the work tracking and thinking close to the code and not needing to switch apps to take notes was a nice reduction of friction.

I have yet to leverage caching of input files locally to get around needing to download the same text files from S3 each time, but I imagine it's [[One of those things that would take five minutes to do]].

title: One of those things that would take five minutes to do

His original essay from 2014 was entitled "Why I hope to Die at 75".
Emanuel: "As you probably know better than everyone else, itâs editors that choose titles and not authors."
**Emanuel will stop taking medication with the sole purpose to prolong his own life after 75, and suggests others might want to consider the same approach.** He doesn't actually hope to die at 75.
He claims that the total people over 75 who continue to be "active and engaged and creative" is a small number, despite the fact that everyone (including me) can think of outliers.
We spend 7x the amount on people 65 and over from the federal budget that we spend on people under 18, despite the claim that children are so important.
Emanuel claims that older people who are still active are largely engaged in "play" activities like hiking etc, and he claims "that's not probably a meaningful life."
I disagree strongly with the premise that a worthwhile objective metric could be used to determine whether or not a given life is meaningful based on its productive outputs.
I think this is a needlessly cynical view, typical of people who just don't like those rascally Silicon Valley Types.

He also claims that [[Peter Thiel]] and [[Larry Ellison]] are fascinated by life extension because they only care about extending their own lives, and aren't interested in life extension more generally.

So is his assignment to a federal commission on COVID concerning? I don't believe so. As I [tweeted](https://twitter.com/ryntck/status/1325887172621328385?s=20), it seems like he's someone who's thought about the utilitarian trade-offs associated with long lives, and assuming he's a qualified professional otherwise, he should be a good fit for the job!

[[Joe Biden]] named [[Ezekiel Emanuel]] to his [[COVID-19]] task force, and a couple people got mad on [[Twitter]] as they do because of his claims about the value of older lives. [This interview](https://www.technologyreview.com/2019/08/21/238642/a-doctor-and-medical-ethicist-argues-life-after-75-is-not-worth-living/) is short and illuminating, and I don't find his views to be particularly off-putting or crazy, despite having three awesome and active grandparents over 80.
[[Idea Sex]] happens when you have a bunch of ideas from a bunch of books floating around in your head. You get a [[compound effect]] as you scale.
Apparently this is how [[Bill Gates]] reads.
[[Tai Lopez]] made this good [[YouTube]] [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulfujUrrWA8) about reading 5-6 books all in one day.

I've definitely retained this view, and take pride in not getting offended by anything. That doesn't imply never being hurt or angered or frustrated, but the idea of taking offense reminds me of some prim and proper high-class aristocrat being offended by rock music or something ridiculous like that.

In my freshman year of [[College]], I have a distinct memory of being in class arguing that [[being offended]] is a choice, since you're necessarily assuming that the other person __should__ have the same sacred cows in mind that you have.

In the very same class as mentioned above, we read both [[The Loss of the Creature]] by [[Walker Percy]] and [[On Truth and Lies in a Nonmoral Sense]] by [[Nietzsche]], both of which were tremendously interesting reads.
[[Mise en place]] is worth meditating on.

Itâs not about scoring goals as much as not letting goals into the net. This simple idea influences your life, and the lives of others. It is the single most influential idea around you."
He claims that there is "no upside" to living in Consistency Space, but I disagree, since consistency is its own upside for those who want it. It's __limited upside__, but not zero.

Work in consistency space is making sure you don't get fired
Work in payoff space is taking risks and reaping the rewards

I've been thinking a lot about the operative truths of my life and what I would consider wisdom that's worth passing on to anyone. Here are some that crossed my path recently:
A consequence of this, of course, is that passing on the right is totally fine, because you're following the only rule you need.
The fact is that this __is__ actually a rule on highways, but it's never enforced and rarely followed. What other [[rules]] are like this?

[[Keep right except to pass]] when driving. My [[Dad]] drilled this into us before we were old enough to drive, pointing out that it's the right default behavior for everyone to keep roads running as smooth as possible.

I've only recently discovered this quote and I don't know who to attribute it to, but it's immensely helpful when trying to figure out whether to dive right in to a problem or step back and think about it a bit first.
I've started to keep this top of mind at work, where the space of possible things to work on is far greater than that of chores around the house, for instance.
[[Act when the cost of failure is low; plan when the cost of failure is high]]

The "I'm not smart enough to understand that" meme is one that just won't fucking die, and it's annoying. Given appropriate incentives to learn, anybody can wrap their head around [[General Relativity]] (something I've tried to understand and have failed to a few times in life).
[[Anyone can learn anything]]
Learning how to use an [[abacus]] seems like a nifty skill to pick up.

Math / Simulations
Airplane seating simulations
Would be easy to build some basic visualization on top of basic data model / processing. Started this project on github.
Answer questions like:
What lineup scheme is best for airplane seating to optimize for time?

On a Southwest flight, given boarding position B34, what is the likelihood that you'll find a window / aisle seat? How far back should you go before just grabbing the first middle seat, trading off between sitting further back etc?
Elevator waiting simulations
Basically the same as above. Given visitor poisson distribution, how long
Land distribution stats for MTG

Understand stats for splashing colors, etc. This math is likely pretty straightforward. Understand possibilities of how lands play out if, for example, I'm playing Llanowar Elves, can dig for basics, etc. Basically, if I want to splash black for Garruk, how many swamps am I actually going to need given the other cards in my deck to be able to pay for him 80% of games once I draw him?
Final trivia statistics
Given 10 teams at trivia, we're in 4th currently, the final trivia category is 80s movies, how much should we wager?

Should take into account existing point distributions, likelihood of average team getting it right, likelihood of other teams betting the house (common bet), likelihood that we're more well-suited to answer it, risk tolerance, need to win, or just get top 3, etc.
Moneyball for fantasy football
I am sure people do this, but it would be neat to add other features. Provide beta distribution graphs for player, team overall, win percentage against opponent's roster, etc.
Art
Overwhelming sensory experience
Create a small room with LEDs covering the walls, insane sound system, maybe really intense HVAC, scents, massage chair, water, etc to completely blast senses.
Open source program generation. Provide configurable controls. Could be a hit at music festivals. Use generative patterns that respond to sound, or not.
Planetarium-style setup could be cool. Single-person or group-of-friends setup.
Physical
Good book holder
I like physical books. I hate sprawling out my fingers under a book. I hate not being able to lie down and just read a book, especially a heavy boy.
Something elegant and physical that would hold a book open and hold its pages back. Page turning would be trivial. Could have a handle to hold instead.
Ideally it could have a thin-enough form factor that just hooking onto the book like a bookmark or something would be acceptable.
Worst case, make something that can prop up on a table.
One-handed bowl lighter
If one were to partake in smoking CBD in a bowl, I might imagine that one might want to be able to do so with one hand.
One may even desire to construct such an object such that it may clip onto said piece.
Nuanced shower handle
Solves the problem of having a tiny range of shower handle available to access reasonable temperatures.
Use some sort of non-linear gear system on a shower handle to make 90% of the handle swing within reasonable shower temps, then rapidly go hot or cold at the ends of the swing.
This would apply equally well to gas stoves, sink faucets, etc.
My guess is that these sorts of gear systems have existed for a hundred years or more, but clearly haven't been applied to showers, where they would be helpful.
Adjustable table umbrella
Umbrellas stationed at tables are good at covering most of the table when the sun is directly overhead, and cover less than that the rest of the time as the sun moves.
A design could be improved by allowing the umbrella to kink in the middle or something to lean in the direction of the sun to shade more of the table.
Apps
Better recipe site

Create a recipe site that doesn't have a 10-page essay and 4000 ads on it. Make it based on graphs. Each node is a step with a duration. Auto-gen an optimized gantt chart. Make the display look really nice. Allow for crowd-sourcing recipes. Ideal for sharing. Leverage common steps to make input easy (eg mince garlic, boil water, etc).
Cooking for engineers or something is a site that starts on this idea but I don't recall it being slick when I last checked it out.
Dumb Alarm
Make a stupid simple alarm app that only ever has one alarm, and only works in 5-minute intervals. One tap to alarm creation.
Insert-only text app

I want to make inboxing thoughts easier. The lightest app possible, automatically bring up the keyboard, hit enter and send thought to pubsub queue or something for later processing. Can configure destination and auth within the app maybe. Could offer hosting.
Middleman

Something that hooks into various jira, github, etc projects and allows you to create edges between nodes. Tie tickets to PRs, etc, have a nice interface for managing the graph. Provide chronological interface as well.
Something interesting about this app not providing any more functionality than basically foreign-keying to other systems and tying things together.

Alternatively, base of app could simply provide nodes as basic text boxes, and provide linking capabilities. This is kind of roam, but have some default `JiraTicketNode`s etc available for more power.

`history`
`history` is a wrapper around `fc -l`
`history 0` shows __all__ available history.
`history -p` "pops" the history stack, but still writes it on shell exit by default.
The history of a current shell is saved ... somewhere, but not as a text file.
`~/.zsh_history` is written to when the current shell exits.
This can be overridden with `SAVEHIST=0` in `~/.zshrc`

The `-u` flag sends unbuffered output to logs, which gives quicker feedback when redirecting a python program's output to a log file, but looks all fucked when using multiple threads.

```yaml
# threading $ p test.py
hello 0
hello 1
hello 2
hello 3
hello 4
hello 5
hello 6
hello 7
hello 8
hello 9 

# threading $ p -u test.py
hello 0hello 1

hello 2
hello 3
hello 4
hello 5
hello 6hello 7
hello 8
hello 9

# threading $ p -u test.py
hello 0
hello 1
hello 2
hello 3
hello 4
hello 5hello 6
hello 7

hello 8
hello 9
```

{{count}}I'm getting the [[iPhone]] 12 Mini delivered today. It's a bittersweet moment parting with my [[iPhone]] 7 that I've had since 2016. We've been through a lot!
You've never had a case. I cracked your screen throwing up outside of [[Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club]] on my birthday, but it wasn't that bad and I never even notice it anymore.
I even cracked the glass on the camera but you're so good at taking photos that you can only notice it at weird angles!
I always appreciated your home button and feel like I might miss it. I'm not bullish about Face ID, but maybe I've just been annoyed with it not recognizing me on my wife's phone.
Every text message I've ever sent to my wife has been sent through you! I got the call that we were pregnant on you! I watched the [[Trump]] show for four years on you!
This year I finally slapped a [[popsocket]] on you and it was a game changer. Thanks for being a good sport about it.
If I'm gonna be an instagram influencer, I just need to take better pictures. You've also been a little sluggish sometimes. That happens to all of us, and that's okay.
I'll find you buried in a tub some day, along with the 3G and the 5, and probably laugh at your buttons and tiny screen (no offense). But the 3G aged well and I'm sure you will too.
Thanks for everything, old buddy. You were a great phone.
A Eulogy for my [[iPhone]] 7

[[Animals]], [[Man]].
It has been really wild how fast it's happened.

He developed a minor limp a few weeks back without an obvious fall or injury. It kind of came and went, but we had a big [[RV Trip]] planned, so we took him to our normal vet to get him checked out. I don't remember if he was limping that day or not. The vet said his elbow popped a bit and we got an x-ray of his leg but no fractures or anything showed up, and we scheduled an appointment with an orthopedic specialist.

While we were on our trip, his limp got progressively worse, and he started to yelp a little when standing up after sleeping for a while. He was otherwise a trooper and went all around the [[Grand Canyon]] and [[Joshua Tree]] and [[White Sands National Park]] and had a grand old time.
So we took him in for his appointment, the doctor noticed a bump on his shoulder, took a CT scan and a biopsy, and let us know a few days later when the results came in.
The biopsy showed a malignant sarcoma, but didn't find any osteoid production, which would have been a clear sign of osteosarcoma.

Currently, our plan is to amputate his front left leg for a clean removal of the scapula and therefore the tumor. This is step one for stopping pain and getting the tumor out of the body and not spreading elsewhere.
It turns out that dogs almost universally adapt well to three legs, so this is a no-brainer. Of all dogs, I feel really good about Mike being an energetic and silly three-legged dog.
After he gets his leg chopped off, they can do a more thorough biopsy on the entire bone to get an idea of what type of cancer we're dealing with.
Osteosarcoma would be bad news, since it's likely to metastasize and often finds its way into the lungs.
We're pretty much braced for this, as it seems to be the most likely situation.
Low-grade [[Chemotherapy]] is the "gold standard" treatment in this case and we could probably expect a little less than two more years of life that way.

Other sarcomas are less likely to metastasize and if it turns out to be one of those, then we have a reasonably lower expectation of needing to expect and treat further cancer flare-ups down the road.
Anyway, good times!kk
We learned last Friday [[January 29th, 2021]] that our little dog [[Michael]] has a big tumor on his scapula that's likely bone [[Cancer]]. He'll be two years old in April.
It's unbelievable how much of that shit has never crossed my mind again since I read it, and unbelievable how I don't really remember writing much of that.
[[Memory]] is wild, man.

> "Existence is random. Has no pattern save what we imagine after staring at it for too long. No meaning save what we choose to impose. This rudderless world is not shaped by vague metaphysical forces. It is not God who kills the children. Not fate that butchers them or destiny that feeds them to the dogs. Itâs us. Only us." - [[Alan Moore]], [[Watchmen]] #quote
https://www.instagram.com/p/CLItu5sJSMB/
Say hello to three-legged Michael!

12 days ago we brought him to the vet for a minor limp, found out it was a 5" malignant tumor in his shoulder bone, and decided to get it out to relieve his pain and get the cancer out before it spread. Lots of action before his second birthday!
He's in good spirits and is getting around like a champ, and he seems to have forgotten already that he ever had a 4th to begin with. Dogs are amazing creatures. Michael especially.

Watching the sweetest dog I've ever known quickly develop and suffer from cancer during his second year of life has been a stark reminder that Nature's basic state is chaos, suffering, death, and decay. No god was there for Michael just as no god is ever there for any of us. Nature will see to it that there will always be innocent sentient beings who needlessly suffer.
And yet, we have our human ingenuity, the only real weapon we have in our struggle against this Void. That, and each other.

The competent and caring veterinary professionals at Blue Pearl using the entire arsenal of modern medicine at their disposal are who we have to thank for Michael's second chance at life. In fact, they're so goddamn good at miracle working, amputations are actually fairly boring procedures with about a 24-hour turnaround time. Whatever they get paid, it's not enough. We live in amazing times.
So here's hoping we stave off the darkness for a good while longer so that Mike's little goofy light can stay bright. He's at least that much more instagrammable now, if nothing else!
Shine on, you crazy doggy.
Text from my [[Instagram]] post about [[Michael]] after his [[Amputation]]
Author:: [[Fareed Zakaria]]
Full Title:: The End of Economics?
Category:: #articles
URL:: https://foreignpolicy.com/gt-essay/the-end-of-economics-fareed-zakaria/

Let me be clear: Economics remains a vital discipline, one of the most powerful ways we have to understand the world. But in the heady days of post-Cold War globalization, when the world seemed to be dominated by markets and trade and wealth creation, it became the dominant discipline, the key to understanding modern life. That economics has since slipped from that pedestal is simply a testament to the fact that the world is messy.

As an aside, if we turn the heat flow around, so that ÎQh flows naturally out of the hot source (ÎQh is negative in this case) and a lesser ÎQc flows into the cold source (positive), the same entropy considerations lead us to derive a maximum amount of work that is extractable from the heat flow, and the efficiency, ÎµÂ =Â ÎW/ÎQh works out to be no better than ÎT/Th. (The bolder among you may want to take up the algebraic challenge.) This is the familiar thermodynamic limit for the amount of work obtainable from a heat engine, like a carâs engine, a coal-fired power plant, or even a nuclear plant. The reason we hit a maximum efficiency is really all about not violating the second law of thermodynamics: that the total entropy of a system may never decrease.

Author:: [[Scott Alexander]]
Full Title:: Meditations on Moloch
Category:: #articles
URL:: https://slatestarcodex.com/2014/07/30/meditations-on-moloch/
Every single citizen hates the system, but for lack of a good coordination mechanism it endures.
From a godâs-eye-view, we can contrive a friendly industry where every company pays its workers a living wage. From within the system, thereâs no way to enact it.

Any human with above room temperature IQ can design a utopia. The reason our current system isnât a utopia is that it wasnât designed by humans. Just as you can look at an arid terrain and determine what shape a river will one day take by assuming water will obey gravity, so you can look at a civilization and determine what shape its institutions will one day take by assuming people will obey incentives.

Increasingly, however, libertarians have ceased to care whether anyone is âpay[ing them] attentionâ â they have been looking for something else entirely: an exit.

Where the progressive enlightenment sees political ideals, the dark enlightenment sees appetites. It accepts that governments are made out of people, and that they will eat well. Setting its expectations as low as reasonably possible, it seeks only to spare civilization from frenzied, ruinous, gluttonous debauch. From Thomas Hobbes to Hans-Hermann Hoppe and beyond, it asks: How can the sovereign power be prevented â or at least dissuaded â from devouring society? It consistently finds democratic âsolutionsâ to this problem risible, at best.
âthe best argument against democracy is a five-minute conversation with the average voterâ

The general tenor of this sensibility is attractive to modern conservatives, because it resonates with their wry, disillusioned acceptance of relentless civilizational deterioration, and with the associated intellectual apprehension of capitalism as an unappetizing but ineliminable default social arrangement, which remains after all catastrophic or merely impractical alternatives have been discarded.

Firstly, it is essential to squash the democratic myth that a state âbelongsâ to the citizenry. The point of neo-cameralism is to buy out the real stakeholders in sovereign power, not to perpetuate sentimental lies about mass enfranchisement. Unless ownership of the state is formally transferred into the hands of its actual rulers, the neo-cameral transition will simply not take place, power will remain in the shadows, and the democratic farce will continue.

Hong Kong, Singapore and Dubai. These states appear to provide a very high quality of service to their citizens, with no meaningful democracy at all. They have minimal crime and high levels of personal and economic freedom. They tend to be quite prosperous. They are weak only in political freedom, and political freedom is unimportant by definition when government is stable and effective.

A simple case of constitutional drift creates two separate governments, one ceremonial and one operational. Bagehot called these âdignifiedâ (Queen Victoria), and âefficientâ (Parliament, Cabinet and Whitehall).
